More Notes: Mean SCCO2 doubles due to increased costs in the Global South.

Empirically derived damage persistence significantly impacts global GDP and its regional distribution, leading to considerable income redistribution detrimental to poorer regions. (Value represents direction of impact)
High persistence with low adaptation can lead to damage caps and SCCO2 estimates of zero.
PAGE-ICE increases SCCO2 relative to PAGE09. (Value represents direction of impact)
Kalkuhl and Wenz DICE. High value provided, but not quantile.
Long-term persistence. High value provided, but not quantile.
Climate parameters conform to IPCC AR5.
Applying a fat-tailed (Gamma) distribution to sea-level rise.
Permafrost feedback.
Non-linear transitions in the sea ice and land snow albedo feedback.
Reduced size, threshold, and lag of discontinuity impacts.
Longer simulation period (until 2300).
Baseline income levels updated to those observed in 2015.
Adjusting the vulnerability of regions in PAGE-ICE to market and non-market damages.
Changing damages to empirical estimates (Burke et al 2015).
Interquartile range calculated based on 50000 Monte Carlo simulations.
5%-95% range based on 50000 Monte Carlo simulations.
Based on panel regression analysis using historical temperature and GDP data (Burke et al 2015).
Mean global GDP in 2100 is 30% lower than SSP2-4.5 growth path without persistence.
Mean growth loss exceeds GDP growth rate in the Global South by 2200, leading to economic contraction.
If 10% of damages persist via reduced growth, there is a fifteenfold increase in mean SCCO2.
The substantial increase in the SCCO2 is primarily driven by the adverse implications for the Global South.
Similar SCCO2 result if only lower-income regions are assumed to suffer from persistent economic damages.
A reduction in damage persistence by at minimum 3% per year would be needed to see a SCCO2 of less than $600.
Current persistence around 50% would need to decrease by more than 2% per year via adaptation efforts to achieve this SCCO2.
The PAGE-ICE model suggests persistent climate-induced economic damages without clear evidence of future adaptation increasing resilience.
